title: All the names and faces of North East criminals jailed in January 2026
body_text:
All the names and faces of North East criminals jailed in January 2026
A number of people were sent to prison in January, some of them given sentences of more than 10 years behind bars - here are their details
These criminals were all locked up in January for their despicable crimes. Some of them were hauled before the courts for horrific sex offences, including rape.
Among the offenders was a child rapist who subjected two vulnerable youngsters to a series of shocking attacks and was locked up for 27 years. Amit Gulati left both schoolgirls traumatised by carrying out vile attacks on them to satisfy his twisted desires.
The 42-year-old was convicted of a total of 19 offences encompassing at least 56 attacks against the victims by a jury at Newcastle Crown Court. He was given the lengthy jail term while his friend, Manideep Bolishetty, who also sexually abused the victims after Gulati introduced him to one of them and encouraged him to molest the other, was convicted of two counts of rape and one of sexual assault and was jailed for seven years. ChronicleLive has previously reported on the criminals who were jailed in December 2025.
Now, we have listed all the criminals jailed in January 2026, as covered by ChronicleLive. The following details include the defendants' pictures, offences and length of sentence handed by judges.
Sean Atkinson
A violent thug stamped on the back of his former partner's head, then brutally snapped her nose back into place after breaking it. Sean Atkinson had already subjected the woman to one horrific attack during which he reversed a car over her, breaking her pelvis and ribs.
But he struck again after accusing her of seeing someone else - after they had split up. Atkinson, 35, of Pelton, County Durham, was found guilty by a jury of inflicting grievous bodily harm and was jailed for three years. Here's the full court report.
John Harris
An alcoholic fraudster exploited an elderly widow out of over £12,000, cleared out her life-savings and sold her dead husband's guitars. John Harris befriended his 75-year-old neighbour and gained her confidence before helping himself to her savings and selling her sentimental belongings.
Harris took out iPhone contracts and bought Apple Mac laptops in her name. He also stole three guitars - one of which was a limited edition - belonging to the victim's deceased husband and sold them on eBay for £1,500.
A court heard that Harris carried out the fraud offences while subject of a community order that he was sentenced to for impersonating a police officer. Harris, of Stephenson Street, Ferryhill, appeared at Durham Crown Court to be sentenced for seven offences of fraud, and one offence of theft. The 35-year-old had pleaded guilty to the offences and was jailed for two years. Here's the full story.
Adam Leddra
A "dangerous" North East paedophile was caged for sexually assaulting a schoolgirl. Adam Leddra committed sexual offences against the victim more than a decade ago.
The brave victim disclosed the abuse to police and Leddra was arrested and interviewed by officers. The 32-year-old - who has previously been jailed for child sex offences - was charged last September.
Leddra, of Rothley, Fatfield, Washington, admitted two charges of sexual activity with a child and two of causing a child to engage in sexual activity. He was sentenced to 33 months in prison. Here's the full story.
Kier Adam-Nuhoglo
A sports coach was left with a double jaw fracture when a city centre thug punched him more than 20 times in a completely unprovoked attack. The victim, who had been out drinking in Newcastle with a friend, was outside Rusty's bar around 3.30am finishing his drink when he noticed a man in the distance.
The man - Kier Adam-Nuhoglo - was shouting aggressively and gesturing towards him and appeared extremely angry, despite the fact there had been no previous interaction between them. Newcastle Crown Court heard the victim's recollection of being attacked is blurry and he believes he may have lost consciousness during it.
Adam-Nuhoglo pleaded guilty to GBH with intent in relation to that attack. While on court bail, he committed further offences against his ex-partner. He pleaded guilty to controlling or coercive behaviour, burglary, strangulation, dangerous driving, having no licence and having no insurance.
The 25-year-old, of Cragside Gardens, Lobley Hill, Gateshead, was jailed for a total of four-and-a-half years. Here's the full court report.
Paul Hogarth, Natalie Garrett
A drug dealer tried to jump out of an upstairs window and flush narcotics away when he was caught red-handed during a police bust. Paul Hogarth was running a lucrative "street-level" dealing operation with the help of "runner" Natalie Garrett, Newcastle Crown Court heard.
Despite not working and being on benefits, more than £80,000 went into his bank account over a two-year period. And when police raided his home in Gateshead, he was caught with drugs, cash and a weapon.
Hogarth and Garrett admitted conspiracy to supply cocaine. Hogarth also admitted possessing cocaine and heroin with intent to supply, possessing criminal property and possessing a knuckle duster in private. Garrett also admitted separate offences of dangerous driving, including doing 86mph in a 30 zone, driving while disqualified and drug driving.
Hogarth, 49, of Waldridge Gardens, Gateshead, was jailed for seven years. Garrett, 34, of Waterloo Street, Newcastle, was locked up for 46 months. Here's the full story.
Paul Logan
A sex predator was finally put behind bars after he raped and abused a child. Paul Logan was jailed for over 11 years.
His crimes remained unpunished until the victim reported him to Northumbria Police years later. And following what officers have described as a "complex investigation" Logan, of Chirton Green, in Blyth, has now faced justice.
The 46-year-old was convicted of two counts of rape and three counts of sexual assault, at Newcastle Crown Court. He was sentenced to 11 years and six months in prison. Here's the full story.
Kristopher Follos
A convicted bank robber used explosives to blow up a cash machine. Kristopher Follos packed the ATM with an improvised explosive device (IED) to try to steal thousands of pounds.
Despite causing huge damage to the machine in Northumberland, Follos and his mystery accomplice were foiled after the explosion failed to provide access to the cash drawers. When officers went to his home, a block of flats where he was living with his mother and where other elderly people also lived, they found three further explosive devices and residents had to be evacuated while they were made safe by the army.
After his arrest, Follos admitted he had carried out two similar attacks on cash machines in the south of England. The 45-year-old, of Olivers Mill, Morpeth, was jailed for eight years at Newcastle Crown Court.
He pleaded guilty to conspiracy to cause explosions of a nature likely to endanger life or cause serious injury to property, conspiracy to steal and making explosive substances with intent. Read the full court report here.
Adreol Mena
A cannabis farm capable of producing thousands of pounds of drugs was busted in a police raid. Police went to a house on Eastgate, Choppington, Northumberland, and having forced entry, they found the property had been turned into a cannabis farm.
There were a total of 67 plants growing in three rooms and it had the potential to crate up to 5.3 kilos of cannabis, worth up to £16,800. Two men were present, including Adreol Mena, who said he was being paid £70 a day to work in the farm. The other man was previously given a suspended prison sentence for his role in the offending.
Mena pleaded guilty to producing cannabis and was jailed for six months. The judge said that, due to the time he had spent on remand, Mena will "either be transferred to immigration or released on post sentence supervision". Here's the full story.
John Jefferson
A thug who attacked a vulnerable man in broad daylight was jailed for six-and-a-half-years. John Jefferson, 65, was driving in Trimdon Station when he jumped out of his car to attack the victim.
Jefferson repeatedly punched and kicked the man several times, before he snatched a gold chain from round his neck and got back into his car. When the victim, who has autism and learning difficulties, tried to sit up, Jefferson got out of his car and continued the sustained attack before fleeing the scene.
Jefferson, of the Trimdon Station area, was soon identified as the suspect by Durham Constabulary officers. He was charged with several offences and was found guilty of attempted grievous bodily harm with intent and robbery after a trial. He was sentenced to a total of six-and-a-half years. Here's the full story.
Victoria Murray
A woman who smashed a man over the head with a Newcastle Brown Ale bottle in a city centre attack was jailed. Psychology graduate Victoria Murray's victim was left "covered in alcohol" and needed stitches for a head wound after the violence in Newcastle city centre.
Murray admitted unlawful wounding. She was sentenced to eight months behind bars. Here's the full story.
Caitlin Simpson
A woman who slashed a man's face left him with a gaping wound which cut through into his mouth. The victim was walking his dog in the Gateshead area when he bumped into Caitlin Simpson and a man.
He knew the man and there was a discussion about the victim selling her fake tan. The trio of them walked together for a while before going their separate ways, Newcastle Crown Court heard.
Around five minutes later, the victim became aware of Simpson running towards him. Neil Pallister, prosecuting, said: "The defendant produced a knife with a Stanley knife type blade and used it to slash him across his face, while shouting and accusing him of calling her brother a nonce.
"The man put his hands up to protect himself and the defendant also cut the palm of his hand during the attack. She then ran away into the estate."
In another offence, Simpson went into a takeaway in Sunderland with a man and they were asked to leave. The takeaway worker, as he had on a number of previous occasions, gave her free food but when she tried to take drinks from the fridge, he took them back from her. She then slapped him and called him a racist name.
When police turned up, she assaulted an officer by grabbing his thigh and digging her nails into his skin. Simpson, 27, of Marian Court, Gateshead, pleaded guilty to wounding with intent, possessing an offensive weapon, racially aggravated common assault, assaulting an emergency worker and possessing cannabis. She was jailed for four years with an extended licence period of a further two years. Here's the full story.
Lee Scott
A respected member of the North East footballing community was unmasked as a child sex pervert. To the outside world, Lee Scott was well-thought-of and played an important role in grassroots football in his community as secretary of Northumberland Football League, although the offences were not related to his role.
The 50-year-old's reputation is now in tatters after he admitted sexually abusing two young girls in separate attacks. He subjected one victim to serious sexual assaults and asked the other to sit on his knee, which she refused, although he then rubbed her leg and asked for a kiss.
Scott, of no fixed address, pleaded guilty to two counts of assaulting a child by penetration and one of causing or inciting a child to engage in sexual activity. He was jailed for six-and-a-half years, of which he has to serve two-thirds behind bars. Here's the full story.
Dalton James Angus
A robber who lunged towards a shopkeeper with a knife was jailed. Dalton James Angus filled a basket with items before legging it out of the shop.
But when the shopkeeper ran after him and tried to retrieve the basket, Angus pulled out a knife and lunged at him before making off from the scene in Dean Bank, Ferryhill. The 23-year-old was later arrested on a park bench after being tracked down by a police drone.
He was charged with robbery and possessing a knife in a public place and put before a court. Angus, of Ferryhill, pleaded not guilty to possessing a knife in a public place and was due to stand trial but later changed his plea and was sentenced to a total of five years in prison. Here's the full story.
Andreas Michael
A woman was saved from a horrific attack in secluded woodland by a heroic member of the public who heard her screams and shouts. The victim had been "wild camping" with partner Andreas Michael when he launched a terrifying attack, pinning her to the ground and raining down blows to her face.
Police received a phone call from a concerned member of the public, saying the woman was being attacked in Watergate Forest Park, in Gateshead. A man was out with his family when they heard raised voices from a secluded area of woodland and a woman's shouting "get off me". The concerned members of the public ran towards the noises and saw Michael repeatedly punching her to the face and she was screaming.
The member of the public struck Michael to the head, knocking him to the ground. The woman's face was swollen and bloodied and she had a significant laceration near one of her eyes.
Michael, 50, of Stainton Drive, Felling, Gateshead, was on a two-year suspended sentence at the time for burglary. He pleaded guilty to assault occasioning actual bodily harm and for that and breaching the suspended sentence he was jailed for 45 months. Read the full story here.
David Wilson
A rape victim was left feeling so dirty after she was attacked, she washed herself with Dettol. David Wilson raped the woman twice during one shocking attack and ignored her desperate pleas for him to stop.
Newcastle Crown Court heard she was left traumatised, scared and felt so dirty she could not initially touch her own skin. She eventually resorted to washing herself with Dettol in a bid to feel clean again.
Wilson, 49, of Garth Farm Road, Winlaton, Gateshead, denied two charges of rape but was convicted by a jury after a trial. He was jailed for 10 years. Here's the full court report.
Irmantas Zilinskas
A terrified woman scrawled 'help' on a car window after being strangled with a towel during a "terrible" attack by her violent partner. Drunken Irmantas Zilinskas subjected his then-partner to a horrific attack that left her feeling she was going to be killed.
Zilinskas launched the attack in a County Durham home after a day of drinking booze and left her gasping for air as he covered her mouth and nose with his hands. At one point, the 39-year-old wrapped a towel around her neck and used it as a ligature as he squeezed it tight.
Zilinskas, of Henry Street, Darlington, appeared at Durham Crown Court to be sentenced for intentional strangulation and intentional suffocation. He pleaded guilty to the offences and was jailed for 36 months. Here's the full report.
Peter Dawson
A man smuggled drugs into a North East prison and passed them to a prisoner hidden in a packet of biscuits. Peter Dawson smuggled 70 Class C tablets into HMP Durham but was caught as he passed them to a prisoner.
A court heard that during the prison visit, Dawson pretended to pick something up from the floor, before placing the drugs on a pack of biscuits. The prisoner then picked up the package and surreptitiously placed it in his mouth, pretending to eat one of the treats.
Dawson, of no fixed address, appeared at Durham Crown Court, charged with bringing a prohibited article into a prison. The 53-year-old had pleaded guilty to the charge and was jailed for seven months. Here's the full story.
Kevin Cruickshanks
A father charged at his son with an axe after driving towards him in a car and ordering a dog to "get" him. Kevin Cruickshanks' victim managed to block the axe attack by closing the front door but now lives in fear he could be killed by his own dad.
Newcastle Crown Court heard the son had gone out to buy a pint of milk in South Shields one morning when he saw Cruickshanks driving towards him "erratically and dangerously" and had to jump out of the way of the vehicle. Cruickshanks then got out of the car, grabbed his son, put his thumbs into his eyeballs and told his dog to "get" him but the animal ran off.
The court heard the victim made his way back to the house he came from but Cruickshanks followed and tried to attack him with an axe. The son said: "If I wasn't fast enough to shut the door he would have taken my face off."
Cruickshanks, 46, of Bewicke Road, Wallsend, admitted possessing a bladed article and causing criminal damage to the door with it. He denied attempted wounding with intent but was convicted by a jury after a trial. He was jailed for five years. Read the full court report here.
Thomas Dodds
A sex predator who stalked a stranger across Newcastle before pouncing on her and trying to rape her was foiled by her bravely fighting him off. Wearing a Newcastle United top, Thomas Dodds set his sights on the victim near Central Station and ran and walked for around half a mile to keep up with her as she rushed home on her own in the early hours.
As she reached the Gateshead end of the High Level Bridge, he struck, taking her to the ground and making a determined effort to rape her. However she stuck her fingers in his mouth and stotted his head off the ground as she courageously fought off his depraved attempt.
Dodds, 22, who had been living with his grandparents in Ashington, pleaded guilty to attempted rape. He was jailed for 63 months. Here's the full court report.
Stephen Cherry, Robi Kingswell
A drug-dealing duo from Newcastle who conspired to supply cocaine across the North East were jailed. Stephen Cherry, Robi Kingswell, and Robbie Bowman, attempted to move the Class A substance throughout the region between March and June 2020.
The men attempted to hide their offending by using 'Encrochat' encrypted messaging, however they were soon the focus of an investigation by specialist officers working as part of Operation Venetic. It soon emerged that Cherry led the conspiracy by organising deliveries with Kingswell, who acted as a storeman, and as a courier alongside Bowman.
The Northumbria Police investigation found that the trio co-ordinated the supply of 11 kilos of cocaine, which is valued in excess of £385,000. The three men were arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to supply Class A drugs in April 2021, and searches of their home addresses were also conducted.
Cherry and Kingswell were charged with conspiracy to supply Class A drugs, while Bowman was charged with being in the concern of supply of Class A drugs. Cherry, 40, of Troutdale Place, Longbenton, Kingswell, 35, of Whitgrave Road, Newcastle and Bowman, 29, of Valley View, Lemington, appeared at Newcastle Crown Court and pleaded guilty.
They then appeared at the same court in January, where Cherry was sentenced to nine years imprisonment, Kingswell sentenced to six years behind bars, and Bowman was sentenced to two years imprisoned, suspended for two years. Here's the full story.
Richard Redhead
A man was jailed for a series of burglaries in Gateshead, including stealing a charity collection tin. Richard Redhead, 37, carried out his crimes in the Swalwell, Dunston and Whickham areas of the town.
Redhead began his crime spree on April 17, forcing entry to premises in Swalwell and stealing drinks, the charity collection tin, and a till with £180 cash inside. A number of other offences then followed.
Redhead, of Clavering Road, Swalwell, was arrested and charged with eight counts of burglary and one of theft, and pleaded guilty. He was sentenced to three years and four months in prison. Here's the full story.
Stephen Scott
A man was jailed after sexually assaulting a teenager as she slept. Stephen Scott abused the victim in South Tyneside.
The victim reported the abuse to police and 26-year-old Scott was charged. He appeared at Newcastle Crown Court where he pleaded guilty to three counts of sexual assault. Scott, of Alder Walk, South Shields, was sentenced to four years and three months in prison. Here's the full story.
Connor Kane
A serial thief banned from the streets and shops he targeted was jailed. Connor Kane was handed a two-year Criminal Behaviour Order (CBO) to keep him out of a number of streets and premises in the Whickham area of Gateshead.
But the 28-year-old repeatedly breached the order throughout December and actively evaded arrest. He was arrested and charged with offences of theft and breaching the CBO by entering stores he was banned from. Kane appeared at Newcastle Magistrates Court, where he was sentenced to nine months behind bars. Here's the full story.
Jai Milligan, Candice Tote
Heinous attackers left an 85-year-old man lying on the floor injured after tricking their way into his home before punching him and stealing his wallet. The elderly victim had just enjoyed watching the Newcastle United's Carabao Cup win parade on TV when his day took a horrific turn at the hands of Jai Milligan and Candice Tote.
The victim, who lived in a bungalow in Walker, Newcastle, was at home when he heard a knock on the window of his back door. He saw a man and woman there and one of them said "Rita sent me". The trick worked and he opened the door and Tote pushed past him, followed by Milligan.
Milligan, of North Shields, pleaded guilty to robbery and was jailed for 73-and-a-half months with an extended licence of a further 12 months. Tote, of no fixed address, admitted common assault and fraud and she was also in breach of a suspended sentence for affray. She was jailed for 21 months. Here's the full court report.
Benjamin Carr
An "extremely aggressive" robber took a woman's car and crashed into a teenage boy while high on crack-cocaine. Benjamin Carr stole a woman's car after forcing her out of the vehicle but was so intoxicated he smashed into a parked Nissan Juke.
He was driving at such speed that he also hit a 14-year-old boy who was walking along the street and left him with a broken collar bone. But rather than help at the scene, Carr instead fled before being arrested.
Carr appeared at Durham Crown Court to be sentenced for robbery, aggravated vehicle taking, driving without insurance, and failing to stop at the scene of an accident. He had pleaded guilty to the offences. He was jailed for four years. Here's the full story.
Nicola Jewers
A woman fraudulently pocketed more than £100,000 in benefits which she was not entitled to. Nicola Jewers carried out benefit fraud over an eight year period by failing to declare her partner had been living with her.
The mother-of-six pleaded guilty to three benefit fraud charges in relation to Employment Support Allowance, Universal Credit and Housing Benefit, between 2016 and 2024. In total, the 43-year-old, of Chapel House Road, Newcastle, received an overpayment of Employment Support Allowance of £64,294, Housing Benefit of £11,500 and Universal Credit of £28,874. She was jailed for 33 months. Here's the full story.
Lisa Taylor
A woman who said setting fire to her bedding was a "cry for help" was jailed. It was in May last year that Lisa Taylor's neighbours saw smoke coming from her downstairs flat in Gateshead.
Taylor, who had made previous threats to set the property alight, set the fire in the rear bedroom. It caused extensive damage and smoke penetrated upstairs.
The court heard that the day before, Taylor had sent messages threatening to burn down the property and she tried to ignite some bedding. A fire investigation showed the blaze had either been started by the ignition of a naked flame to combustible material or she had carelessly disposed of smoking material.
Taylor pleaded guilty to arson being reckless as to whether life was endangered. She was jailed for 28 months. Here's the full story.
Mark Hardy
A raging brute repeatedly strangled his partner until her eyes bulged and she passed out, then dragged her to a barn and threatened to kill her while wielding an axe. After looking through the victim's phone and seeing a text he didn't like, Mark Hardy became enraged and punched her in the face numerous times.
He then squeezed the mum's neck with so much force she felt her eyes bulging before losing consciousness. The court heard this happened on several occasions and he also spat in her face.
Hardy then dragged her to a barn at the victim's home on a Northumberland farm and used an axe to smash her phone while saying he was going to kill her. The victim had managed to hide her daughter's phone in her clothing during the ordeal and surreptitiously called the emergency services.
Hardy, 28, of Chantry Estate, Corbridge, pleaded guilty to strangulation, assault and criminal damage. He was jailed for three years and two months. Read the full story here.
Daniel Conroy
A brute was jailed after a horror attack left a woman 'covered in blood', and a neighbour was subsequently blamed by the perpetrator, leading police to wrongfully arrest him for attempted murder. For the shocking incident, and the lies that followed, Daniel Conroy was sentenced to a spell in prison.
Conroy, of Clifton Road, Darlington, was jailed for two years and 11 months after admitting perverting the course of justice, section 20 wounding without intent and assault by beating, relating to an earlier violent incident. Here's the full story.
Paris Griffiths, Alexander Reeves
Vile attackers left a man in intensive care by stabbing him, subjecting him to a 'sickening' assault and pouring boiling water over him. Paris Griffiths and Alexander Reeves launched the violence after a "binge" on crack cocaine and pink gin.
Newcastle Crown Court heard the pair who were covered in blood and bodily fluid, then bragged and laughed about the attack that left the victim with stab wounds and seriously ill. Griffiths admitted causing grievous bodily harm with intent as well as possessing class C drugs and was jailed for six years and 11 months. Reeves admitted causing grievous bodily harm with intent and was jailed for eight years. Here's the full story.
Susanne Redhead
A family firm almost went under when their accounts manager stole £767,000 and blew it all on gambling in an "utterly disgusting" betrayal of trust. Susanne Redhead stole the staggering sums from under the noses of her employer and put the jobs of friends and colleagues at risk, a court heard.
Redhead had worked for Newcastle-based Pure Panel Management since 2010 and had worked her way up to become accounts manager, with no one above her in the accounts department. Her offending came to light in January 2025, when it emerged she had been making regular payments to herself, including £100,000 in the previous seven days and £363,000 in December 2024 alone.
When she was told to stop working immediately, she replied: "I knew this was coming. I've been gambling." A subsequent investigation showed that between November 2023 and January 2025, she had stolen £767,272 in 445 separate transactions.
Redhead, 53, of Wroxham Court, in Newbiggin Hall, Newcastle, pleaded guilty to theft and was jailed for three years. Read the full court report here.
Peter McAskill
A paedophile who breached a court order and targeted vulnerable children online was jailed for five years. Peter McAskill used pseudonyms online to trick children online into believing he was their age. He would then encourage them to send sexually explicit pictures of themselves to him.
McAskill was arrested in August 2023 and was later made subject to a Sexual Risk Order (SRO) after it became clear to officers his offending centred around young children. During questioning, McAskill denied any involvement in his requesting and possession of the indecent images, however digital forensic officers soon disproved these claims.
McAskill, of West End Road, Berwick, was charged with a string of child sexual offences including making indecent images of children, possession of extreme pornography and possessing a prohibited image of a child. He pleaded guilty to all charges at Newcastle Crown Court and was sentenced to five years in prison. Here's the full story.
Freddy Smith, aka Campbell
A pregnant woman was left in "pain so bad you think you are already dead" during a shocking campaign of gratuitous violence and humiliation by her partner. Freddy Smith, also known as Campbell, attacked the victim with weapons including sword and razor blade, made her go outside naked and made her drink his blood, a court heard.
Many of his attacks took place when she was pregnant with his child, between 2021 and 2022 and the victim said he became "bad Freddy" from around January 2022. Smith, of East Lea, Winlaton, Gateshead, pleaded guilty to wounding with intent, wounding, four counts of assault occasioning actual bodily harm, strangulation and controlling or coercive behaviour.
He was jailed for six years with an extended licence period of a further three years. Here's the full court report.
John McGrath
A rogue builder was jailed after a string of fraud offences which left his customers thousands of pounds out of pocket. John McGrath, of The Oval, Barnard Castle, County Durham, was sentenced to 15 months due to the string of crimes he committed.
The case was heard at Teesside Crown Court after it was brought forward by Durham County Council and National Trading Standards. The council began investigating after receiving a complaint from one of McGrath's customers, unravelling the offences which he made between 2016 and 2021.
The court heard that McGrath’s activity would generally begin with him agreeing to carry out building or roofing work, and he would then request more money from his customers, but would not return. He would also promise customers a refund but would not compensate in full or, in some cases, would not return any money at all.
McGrath pleaded guilty to eight counts of fraud, and he was sentenced to imprisonment of 15 months, serving half in custody and half on licence. Here's the full story.
Callum Barnes
Callum Barnes sparked a major blaze by torching a stranger's home for no apparent reason. The victim was not in when Barnes started two fires at his property in Sunderland but was confronted by the flames when he returned.
Newcastle Crown Court heard the fires damaged the front of the house, including the upstairs window, a Ford transit van, a shed and some conifers. The court heard the householder was a roofing contractor and the damage to the van, plus the tools inside it, cost him £3,000.
Barnes, of Shiney Row, Sunderland, admitted arson being reckless to whether life would be endangered. He was jailed for three years. Here's the full story.
Steward Strong
A drugged and dangerous driver kept a police chase going even after officers burst his tyres. It was just before 2am on October 16 that police spotted Steward Strong driving an Audi in Ashington, heading towards Newbiggin.
Newcastle Crown Court heard officers signalled for him to pull over but he made off at speed, sparking a chase. A police helicopter spotted him in the Killingworth area and a stinger device was used to try to bring him to a stop. But even after his tyres were burst, he continued driving.
Strong, of Choppington, Northumberland, was on a suspended prison sentence at the time for a commercial burglary and theft, imposed in 2024. He pleaded guilty to dangerous driving, driving without a licence or insurance, drug driving and possessing cocaine. For that, and breaching the suspended sentence, he was jailed for 26 months. Here's the full story.
Matthew Bello
A Northumbria Police officer was injured in a vicious machete attack, with the man responsible jailed for four years. Roads Policing Constable Will Hunter was assaulted when he stopped a car at a petrol station in Leam Lane, Gateshead.
When offender Matthew Bello was challenged around his insurance, he launched a violent attack on the officer, with the machete causing an injury to his arm. Bello fled the scene in his car, ramming the police vehicle and leaving PC Hunter injured in the road, before he was arrested in the nearby Saltwell area.
He was originally charged with attempted murder but later pleaded guilty to the lesser offence of wounding with intent. He was sentenced to four years for wounding with intent, possession of a knife in a public place, dangerous driving and no insurance. Read the full story here.
Thomas Hobbs
Vile sex beast Thomas Hobbs was jailed for 22 years after he was convicted of raping and deliberately burning a young child. Hobbs was separately abusing two children at around the same time and was previously jailed for 19 years for attacking the first victim.
In January, the 79-year-old was told he would serve even longer behind bars after jurors found him guilty of attacking the second victim in Northumberland. Newcastle Crown Court heard the girl said Hobbs would tell her they were "just playing" before carrying out the abuse. Afterwards, he would ask if she had liked what he did and when she said no he reacted angrily.
When the victim came forwards, the earlier case against Hobbs was already in the court system. For that offending, he was jailed for 19 years in September 2024 after he was convicted of ten offences, including rape and sexual assaults.
For the latest offences, he was found guilty by jury of rape, causing a child to engage in sexual activity, assault by penetration and assault occasioning actual bodily harm in relation to the burning. He was sentenced to 22 years with an extended licence period of a further year. That sentence will run concurrently to the 19 year sentence imposed in 2024. Read the full court report here.
Amit Gulati, Manideep Bolishetty
A child rapist who subjected two vulnerable youngsters to a series of shocking attacks was locked up for 27 years. Amit Gulati left both schoolgirls traumatised by carrying out vile attacks on them to satisfy his twisted desires.
The 42-year-old was convicted of a total of 19 offences encompassing at least 56 attacks against the victims by a jury at Newcastle Crown Court. He was given the lengthy jail term while his friend, Manideep Bolishetty, who also sexually abused the victims after Gulati introduced him to one of them and encouraged him to molest the other, was also locked up.
Gulati, of Beaumont Street, Blyth, who was found guilty of multiple offences of rape and other sexual offences, was jailed for 27 years plus an extended licence period of a further year. He will have to serve two-thirds of the 27 years behind bars.
Bolishetty, 27, of Tamworth Road, Newcastle, was convicted of two counts of rape and one of sexual assault. He was jailed for seven years. Read the full court report here.
Daryl McBurnie
An ex-Army serviceman bit his partner and held a knife to her throat during a violent and controlling relationship. Daryl McBurnie subjected his then-partner to assaults and isolation during their five year relationship and left her requiring medication.
In one terrifying attack, the 28-year-old bit the woman several times and left her with visible injuries. During another incident a month later, McBurnie bit her again and held a knife to her throat in her County Durham home.
McBurnie appeared at Durham Crown Court to be sentenced for coercive or controlling behaviour and two counts off assault occasioning actual bodily harm. He had pleaded guilty to the offences and was jailed for 27 months. Here's the full story.
Trevor Murphy

Ryan Hodgson
A road menace was involved in a major crash with police cars following a high speed pursuit. Ryan Hodgson had already served a prison sentence imposed in 2023 for dangerous driving when he got behind the wheel again while banned.
It was in March last year that police spotted Hodgson behind the wheel of a Seat Ibiza on Hawthorn Road, in Gosforth, Newcastle. Police signalled for him to pull over but he ignored them and sped off.
He reached speeds of 80mph in a 30mph zone and carried out dangerous manoeuvres, including going through a red light and forcing other vehicles onto the other side of the road. Hodgson, who had two passengers in the car, was brought to a crashing halt on a roundabout near the A1 when he was hit by two police vehicles, causing serious damage after he span out of control and crashed into a barrier at the side of the road.

He denied the offences when interviewed by officers and was subsequently charged with six counts of indecent assault on a girl under 14 years and one count of gross indecency with a girl under 14 years - being that the offences occurred before the Sexual Offences Act was introduced in 2003.
